Appendix 4  1 
 
PROJECT PREPARATORY TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
1.  The project preparatory technical assistance (the TA) is needed to ensure that the 
design and preparation of the Zhelin Lake Water Resources Integrated Utilization Project (the 
project) proposed by the government of the People’s Republic of China (PRC) can fully meet 
the loan processing requirements of the Asian Development Bank (ADB), and be suitable for 
ADB lending support.   
B.  Major Outputs and Activities 
2.  The major output of the TA will be a project design for a loan which responds to the 
needs of the clients and fulfills the requirements and safeguards policies of ADB. The delivery of 
consulting services under the TA requires an innovative approach to suit the complex nature of 
the project. The TA will (i) assess the project’s technical, financial, and economic feasibility; (ii) 
review  environmental  and  social  safeguards  compliance;  (iii)  prepare  and  revise  project 
documents  to  meet  ADB’s  requirements;  (iv)  assist  in  preparing  project  implementation 
schedules; and (v) conduct training and capacity development. The key outputs and activities 
are summarized in Table A4.1.  
Table A4.1: Summary of Major Outputs and Activities 
Expected  Expected 
Major Activities  Completion Date  Major Outputs  Completion Date 
Conduct initial assessment  By Feb 2013  Inception report  By end Feb 2013

Appendix 4  2 
 
C.  Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement  
3.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000 equivalent, of which $750,000 will be financed 
on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other sources). The 
government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  office 
accommodation,  and  transportation  for  project  site  visits.  The  detailed  cost  estimates  are 
presented in Table A4.2.  
Table A4.2: Cost Estimates and Financing Plan

D.  Consulting Services 
4.  It is expected that 13 person-months of international and 40 person-months of national 
consultants are required. The consultants will support the executing and implementing agencies 
in completing the project feasibility studies and safeguard documents to a standard consistent 
with the requirements of ADB and the government. The consultants will also provide start-up 
project implementation support to the executing and implementing agencies. ADB’s Guidelines 
on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time) will be applied in recruiting

Appendix 4  3 
 
consultants.  Table  A4.3  provides  details  of  the  required  expertise.  The  outline  terms  of 
reference for the TA consultants are described in paras. 5–14 below.   
Table A4.3: Summary of Consulting Services Requirement 
International  Person- National  Person-
Name of Position  month  Name of Position  month 
Water supply specialist/team leader  5.0  Water supply specialist/deputy team leader  6.0 
Economic and financial specialist  2.0  Economic and financial specialist  4.0 
Social development and resettlement  2.0  Social development and resettlement  5.0 
specialist  specialist 
   
Environment specialist  3.0  Environment specialist  4.0 
Structural design engineer  1.0  Structural design engineer  3.0 
Water demand management specialist  3.0 
PES specialist  3.0 
    Pollution management specialist  2.0 
    Biodiversity conservation specialist  3.0 
    Financial management specialist  2.0 
    Institutional and capacity development   
    specialist  2.0 
    Project management and procurement   
        specialist  3.0 
Total  13.0  Total  40.0 
PES=Payment for Environmental Specialist 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates. 
 
5.  Water  supply  specialists/team  leader  and  deputy  team  leader  (international,  5 
person-months  [pm];  national,  6  pm).  The  specialists  will  have  a  degree  in  water  supply, 
environmental  management,  or  other  related  fields;  10-year  work  experience  in  project 
development and implementation; and familiarizing with ADB’s project processing requirements. 
The team leader will have the overall responsibility for TA coordination and implementation, and 
quality of all PPTA outputs. Specifically, the specialists will (i) prepare a sector assessment 
report based on relevant literature and policies documents such as the Master Plan of Jiujiang 
Municipality; (ii) conduct stakeholder analysis, and develop the project design and monitoring 
framework (DMF); (iii) assess the feasibility of public-private partnerships, in particular service 
contract, from the legal, regulatory and institutional perspectives; (iv) review the overall project 
design;  (v)  recommend  a  project  performance  monitoring  system;  (vi)  prepare  the 
implementation  schedule  and  detailed  implementation  arrangements;  (vii)  analyze  lessons 
learned from the  previous  projects financed  by  ADB,  other  development  partners  and the 
government; and incorporate them in the project design; (viii) prepare inception, interim, draft 
final,  and  final  reports;  and  (ix)  organize  and  implement  trainings  for  the  executing  and 
implementing agencies. 
6.  Economic  and  financial  specialists  (international  2  pm;  national,  4  pm).  The 
specialists will have a degree in economics or finance, and 7-year work experience in economic 
and financial analyses of ADB- or World Bank-financed projects. The specialists will (i) review 
and prepare project cost estimates, financing plan, and financial projections; (ii) conduct project 
economic and financial analyses, covering demand analysis, least economic cost analysis, 
economic  and  financial  cost-and-benefit  analysis,  economic  and  financial  internal  rates  of 
return, sensitivity analysis, and benefit distributional analysis; (iii) design and conduct survey 
and collect secondary data to assess water tariff willingness-to-pay, affordability analysis, as 
well as other issues related to economic analysis; (iv) identify financing mechanisms for project 
cost recovery, with consideration to differential tariffs and other alternatives to enable access for 
the poor; (vi) review the fund flow, loan repayment, and disbursement arrangements; and (vii)

Appendix 4  4 
 
provide inputs to the sector assessment report looking at how future economic growth scenarios 
will affect water sector and the optimal actions to adapt.  
 
7.  Social development and resettlement specialists (international, 2 pm; national, 5 
pm). The specialists will have a degree in social science and/or development studies and at 
least 10-year work experience in resettlement and/or social development conducting social 
analysis, preferably including gender analysis. The specialists will have extensive experience 
working with international development partners, and preferably experience in urban and rural 
water supply projects. The specialists will (i) work with economic and financial specialists to 
design, prepare and conduct surveys, and  collect secondary data on vulnerability issues, 
affordability  issues,  poverty  and  inequality  in  the  project  area  and  among  the  project 
beneficiaries, water-related health conditions, and other social and poverty related issues as 
needed; (ii) conduct a poverty and social analysis following ADB’s Handbook on Social Analysis 
(Manila, 2007) and other relevant documents, and internationally-recognized best practice; (iii) 
prepare poverty and social profiles, and a Poverty and Social Assessment report commensurate 
with project impact and opportunities; (iv) assess how the project  can benefit the people, 
particularly the poor and vulnerable households, prepare a Social Action Plan (SAP), establish 
what baseline data will be collected, and ensure that measures under the SAP are taken into 
account for project design; (v) conduct a gender analysis and assess how the project can 
benefit gender equality using ADB’s relevant sector gender checklists and toolkits, prepare a 
Gender Action Plan based on the requirements of ADB’s Guidelines for Gender Mainstreaming 
Categories of ADB Projects (2012), establish what baseline data will be collected, and ensure 
that measures under the GAP are taken into account for project design; (vi) review resettlement 
plans prepared, conduct surveys, assess the resettlement impact, and assist in preparing the 
draft and final resettlement plans meeting ADB requirements, in particular the SPS and its 
Safeguard  Requirement  2  (Manila,  2009),  and  following  standards  laid  out  in  other 
documentation, and ensure procedural compliance with ADB procedures; (vii) review available 
sources and collect data to review project’s IP categorization as C; in particular impacts on IP, if 
any, in areas impacted by or benefiting from the project in the upstream areas; should there be 
a reason to trigger the SPS Safeguard Requirement 3, inform ADB accordingly and prepare an 
IP planning document commensurate with the impact on IP; (viii) prepare a concise consultation 
and participation plan and a stakeholder communication strategy for project implementation, 
following ADB’s Strengthening Participation for Development Results: An Asian Development 
Bank Guide to Participation (Manila, 2012); and (ix) assist in developing the DMF through 
participatory approach, particularly on identifying proper social indicators for the DMF. 
 
8.  Environment specialists (international, 3 pm; national, 4 pm). The specialists will have 
a degree in environmental studies and 10-year work experience in environmental assessment. 
Based on the domestic reports and rapid field surveys, the specialists will (i) review the draft 
domestic  environmental  safeguard  reports; (ii)  obtain  any  additional  information  needed  to 
comply with ADB’s requirements; (iii) prepare consolidated Environmental Impact Assessment 
which  complies  with  ADB  requirements,  including  assessment  and  description  of  project 
potential  environmental  benefits  and  impacts,  environmental  management  plan  comprising 
mitigation measures, a mitigation and monitoring program and cost estimates, description of 
habitats and biodiversity values, general characterization of the Xiu river catchment, boundary 
of impacts, institutional arrangements, implementation schedule, public consultations, grievance 
redress mechanism, and maps and diagrams, as necessary. The monitoring program will be 
developed for integration within the project performance monitoring system to be prepared by 
the team leader (see para. 5); (iv) identify ‘associated facilities’ to the project and, if necessary, 
conduct due diligence on potential relevant environmental issues of these facilities as per ADB 
Safeguard Policy Statement (SPS); (v) review the reports prepared by other specialists and

Appendix 4  5 
 
integrate their findings into the environmental assessment, highlighting in particular (a) potential 
impacts of inundation as a result of creating an impoundment downstream of the current Zhelin 
lake reservoir; and (b) required minimum ecological flows, and potential downstream impacts of 
the project on the Poyang lake wetland complex and its attendant biodiversity; (vi) coordinate 
with the social development plans for the inputs to be covered in the consolidated environmental 
impact assessment, including livelihood issues related to environment; and (vii) assess initial 
climate change impacts, and recommend policy and investment options on how to cope with 
climate change. 
9.  Structural Design Engineers (international, 1 pm; national, 3 pm). The specialists will 
have a university degree in hydraulic engineering and over 10 years of experience in designing 
hydraulic engineering projects in a variety of countries. The specialists will: (i) review detailed 
designs of the weir, small hydropower, water division, transmission pipeline, water treatment, 
and  distribution  pipeline  in  the  project  and  verify,  among  others  (a)  the  list  of  suggested 
investments; (b) hydraulic calculations; (c) assessment of environmental impacts; (d) plant, 
equipment, materials, and construction standards; (e) detailed civil and mechanical designs; (f) 
bill of quantities and detailed cost estimates; and (g) drawings required for construction and 
installation works; (ii) review the overall subcomponent design of weir in the context of the 
relevant ADB policies and guidelines, and examine the height and general layout of weir, paying 
special attention to (a) design of the chosen weir type, division, and spillway mechanism; (b) 
suitability of the spillway design criteria and assess the consequences of weir overtopping; (c) 
source and suitability of construction materials for the weir; (d) technical specifications of the 
bidding documents; and (e) cost estimates, including unit costs and estimates of quantities and 
provide input to the financial analysis and financial management specialist to estimate price and 
physical contingencies; (iii) identify the project’s key technical risks and provide input to the 
economic model for sensitivity and risk analyses; (iv) identify ‘associated facilities’ to the project 
and if necessary, conduct due diligence on potential structural issues of relevance as per ADB 
SPS (e.g., structural integrity of the Zhelin lake dam located upstream of the proposed project 
impoundment);  and  (v)  review  the  technical  capacity  and  experience  of  executing 
agency/implementing agency staff to design, supervise, and manage the implementation of 
project facilities.    
 
10.  Water demand management specialist (national, 3 pm). The specialist will have a 
degree in water resources planning and management and at least 10-year work experience in 
water conservation and demand management. Specifically, the specialist will (i) prepare a report 
on international experience with demand management and the implications for applying in the 
Jiujiang Municipality, and this report will serve as an input for sector assessment; (ii) conduct a 
detailed water resources systems analysis of the project area by defining the system, identifying 
its boundaries, identifying the functions, assessing water demand and supply in-depth and with 
temporal and spacial variations, looking at upstream and downstream issues and cross-border 
effects,  and  analyzing  inter-sectoral  trade-offs,  cross-coordination,  and  interaction  between 
potential projects; (iii) for the demand and supply analysis, further conduct (a) risks in demand 
projections;  (b)  risks  in  water  supply  availability;  (c)  shortage  assessment  under  low  flow 
conditions, including the need for environmental flow allocation; (d) causes of non-revenue 
water;  (e)  a  water  balance  study,  to  ascertain  the  effect  of  current  and  proposed  water 
extraction from the lake; (iv) for drought management program, further conduct: (a) emergency 
program; (b) long-term drought program; and (v) based on the above-mentioned results, design 
practical measures/strategies to shift water governance in JMG towards demand management, 
including detailed measures of: river basin planning, water permit system, quota management, 
pricing and tariff and water saving, reduction in non-revenue water. The specialist will work with

Appendix 4  6 
 
the environmental and biodiversity specialists and other team specialists, as necessary, to 
ensure that all water uses are considered. 
 
11.     Payments for environmental services specialist (national, 3 pm). The specialist will 
have  extensive  experience  in  natural  resources  management  and  payment  for  ecological 
services (PES) system design, with a graduate degree in related subjects. The specialist will 
also have extensive experience and an excellent understanding of the PRC's institutional setting 
in water quality control and inter-municipal fiscal transfer. Specifically, the specialist will: (i) 
identify critical indicators that must be monitored by the water quality monitoring system to be 
established at the intake of the intended impoundment at the downstream of Zhelin lake, and 
provide  recommendations  on  how  to  establish  a  comprehensive  monitoring  system  and  a 
database to share the collected data with relevant stakeholders; (ii) review the permits that have 
been issued for all developments in the upstream of the Zhelin Lake. Determine how the permits 
for discharge of any water from any development, existing or proposed, could be revised to 
prevent pollution of the reservoir waters; (iii) review and revise the proposed pollution monitoring 
system (self and independent monitoring), review in general the water quality in all the rivers in 
Xiu river and what inputs should be done to improve the permitting/monitoring system; (iv) 
develop a survey framework for upstream stakeholder analysis and assessment of the costs 
(both  direct  and  indirect)  incurred  in  the  upstream  areas  for  water  quality  preservation  to 
determine the appropriate scale and level of payments for PES mechanism; (v) assess the 
institutional  and  fiscal  feasibility  for  introducing  an  inter-municipal  fiscal  transfer  between 
Yongxiu, and Xiushui counties and JMG; (vi) develop a PES implementation strategy that 
includes,  among  others,  inter-county  fiscal  transfer  mechanism,  mechanisms  to  collect  (in 
downstream  areas)  and  distribute  (in  upstream  areas)  the  compensation,  and  institutional 
arrangement;  and  (vii)  identify  capacity  building  needs  and  awareness  raising  activities  of 
relevant stakeholders for effective implementation of PES that is linked to the water quantity and 
quality.  
 
12.  Pollution management specialist (national, 2 pm). The specialist will have a degree in 
environment or relevant field, and at least 7-year work experience in pollution management. The 
specialist will (i) review the relevant government policy and plans regarding water resources 
protection and pollution management in Xiu river watershed; (ii) assess the pollution status in 
Xiu River, particularly around the potential drinking water protection zone in the Zhelin lake, 
including contributions of different polluting sources from sub-regions; (iii) review the measures 
of managing pollution sources in the Xiu River and associated costs, and propose cost-effective 
measures for mitigating and reducing point source and nonpoint source pollution; and (iv) assist 
in designing wastewater treatment plants and pilot programs for managing non-point source 
pollution in the project. 
 
13.    Biodiversity conservation specialist (national, 3 pm). The specialist will have an 
advanced degree in biological sciences and at least 10 years of professional experience in 
wetland ecology, aquatic biology, and biodiversity (especially birds and other wetland fauna). 
Experience in projects that assess impacts to watersheds and/or wetlands is preferred. The 
specialist will: (i) describe the biodiversity values and potential impacts within the project sites; 
(ii) evaluate the impacts and benefits that project activities will have on biodiversity resources in 
the upper watershed of the Xiu River, including the Xiu River Nature Reserve; (iii) assess how 
the project may cause changes in flow regimes (seasonal timing, duration, and volume) of water 
flowing into the Poyang Lake and wetland system. The following tasks are to be carried out 
depending upon the extent to which the project actions may affect downstream flows: (a) assess 
how  changes  in  downstream  flows  affect  habitats  in  the  Poyang  Lake  system,  including 
changes  in  seasonal  extent  of  shallow-water  and  deep-water  zones,  aquatic  vegetation,

Appendix 4  7 
 
mudflats, and other critical habitats for waterbirds, finless porpoise, and other species; (b) 
describe  the  species  and  groups  which  may  be  affected  by  project  activities,  including  a 
summary of their seasonal status, distribution, and abundance in the Poyang Lake system and 
accompanied by maps showing areas of feeding/breeding habitat and how these may be altered 
by the project activities; (c) assess potential impacts, including specific assessment of whether 
the Project will cause impacts to critical habitat; (d) recommend mitigation measures, especially 
measures that could be undertaken to improve wildlife habitat, or more effectively manage 
populations of rare, threatened, or endangered species, and summarize net impacts; and (e) 
determine whether impacts to critical biodiversity habitat can be sufficiently avoided, reduced 
and/or mitigated, and if not, whether an offset program is required. If so, prepare an offset 
program. 
 
14.  Financial management specialist (national, 2 pm). The specialist will have a degree in 
financial management and at least 5-year work experience in project financial management 
assessment. The specialist will (i) conduct a financial management assessment of the executing 
and  implementing  agencies;  (ii)  assess  their  policies  and  capacity  for  financial  and 
disbursement  management  and  identify  any  further  need  for  capacity  building;  (iii)  review 
existing procedures for disbursement, funds flow, and approvals; and recommend streamlined 
funds flow and procedures for contracting and disbursement under the project, and internal 
control and audits; (iv) review onlending arrangements; and (v) assist in financial projections 
and financial analysis.  
 
15.  Institutional and capacity development specialist (national, 2 pm). The specialist will 
have a degree in management or related field, and at least 5-year work experience with ADB or 
other externally funded projects. Experience with ADB- or World Bank-financed projects in the 
water supply and/or water resources management sectors is expected. The specialist will (i) 
assess the institutional settings for generic water resources management and for the project; (ii) 
review, assess, and prepare the institutional impacts of the project following ADB guidelines; (iii) 
assess the existing management for water resources protection and water supply in the project 
area  and  their  capacity,  and  propose  institutional  and  capacity  development  plans  to  be 
included in the project; and (iv) recommend measures for improving performance, and operation 
and maintenance of the water supply utilities. 
 
16.  Project management and procurement specialist (national, 3 pm). The specialist will 
have a degree in engineering and at least 7-year work experience in project management, and 
procurement  and  consulting  services.  The  specialist  will  (i)  conduct  procurement  capacity 
assessment  for  the  executing  and  implementing  agencies  to  undertake  procurement  and 
consultant recruitments envisaged under the project; (ii) prepare a procurement plan, including: 
(a) contract packages indicating the procurement method for each contract and the source of 
financing; and (b) indicative procurement schedule and implementation schedule indicating the 
tasks on the critical path; (iii) assess the capacity of the executing and implementing agencies 
for project implementation, and prepare training proposals to be included under the project; (iv) 
provide necessary trainings on project management, procurement, and consulting services; and 
(v) assist in developing the design and monitoring framework and performance targets. 
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  JMG, represented by the Jiujiang Development and Reform Commission (JDRC), will be 
the executing agency of the project. A multiagency leading group (LG) at the municipal level, 
chaired by the Mayor of JMG and comprising senior officials from both participating counties 
(De’an, Gongqing, Xiushui, Wuning, and Yongxiu) and the bureaus of finance, development and

Appendix 4  8 
 
reform  commission,  water  resources,  construction,  environmental  protection,  forestry,  land 
resources, construction planning, transportation, road, cultural and media, water utility, and 
JCCIL,  will  ensure  coordination  across  sectors  and  guide  project  preparation  and 
implementation.  A  project  management  office, based  in  the  JDRC,  will  be  responsible  for 
coordinating the preparation and implementation of the project. A consulting firm will be selected 
by ADB based on the quality- and cost-based selection method using a quality–cost ratio of 
90:101 and simplified technical proposals. The equipment will be procured following ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). The training and workshop 
funds will be administered through the consultants. The disbursement will be done following 
ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
The TA will be implemented from 1 January 2013 to 31 October 2013. 
 
18.  The proposed TA processing and implementation schedule is listed in Table A4.4.  
 
Table A4.4: Proposed Technical Assistance Processing and Implementation Schedule 
Major Milestones       Expected Completion Date 
TA approval  IV October 2012 
Recruitment of TA consultants  October 2012–January  2013 
Inception  February 2013 
Interim report  April 2013 
Draft final report  July 2013 
Final report  October 2013 
TA closing  December 2013 
TA = technical assistance. 
Source: Asian Development Bank estimates. 
 
                                                
1  The reason for using 90:10 as the quality-cost ratio is due to complexity of the project, which requires highly-
qualified consultant team.
